title: Desire & Frequency
description: Explore your expectations and feelings about intimate frequency.

questions.text: When it comes to how often I desire physical intimacy, I'd say...
choices: Frequently—it's important to me
Regularly but not constantly
It varies a lot for me
Less often than many people

therapeutic.rationale: Desire frequency is one of the most common sources of couple conflict. High-desire partners feel rejected when turned down; lower-desire partners feel pressured. Neither is wrong—desire varies naturally between people.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Desire discrepancy is normal but needs management. The higher-desire partner shouldn't feel like a burden; the lower-desire partner shouldn't feel inadequate. Find your compromise frequency.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched desire frequency is a gift. You'll naturally want intimacy at similar rates.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How often do you ideally want physical intimacy? Has that changed over time or in different relationships?

questions.text: My desire for intimacy is most affected by...
choices: How emotionally connected I feel
My stress levels and what's happening in life
How physically rested and well I am
The quality of recent intimate experiences

therapeutic.rationale: Desire triggers vary. Emotional-connectors need closeness first; stress-affected types fluctuate with life; physical-wellness types need rest; quality-focusers respond to good experiences. Knowing your partner's triggers helps you nurture desire.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different desire triggers mean different nurturing. The emotional-connector may not respond to physical cues; the stress-affected partner may need life to calm down first. Learn each other's accelerators.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared desire triggers make nurturing intimacy easier. You'll naturally create the right conditions.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What increases your desire? What decreases it? Be honest and specific.

questions.text: When there's a difference in desire between us, I'd want us to...
choices: Talk about it openly without blame
Find compromises that work for both
Give each other grace without pressure
Understand it's normal and not take it personally

therapeutic.rationale: How couples handle desire differences predicts relationship satisfaction. Talkers process openly; compromisers find middle ground; grace-givers prioritize acceptance; normalizers reduce shame. All approaches can work.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different handling preferences are fine—you can do all of these. The key is avoiding criticism, defensiveness, and shutting down.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared handling approach makes navigating differences smoother. You'll naturally respond to mismatches the same way.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you want desire differences handled? What response would hurt? What would help?

questions.text: When I'm not in the mood but my partner is, I usually...
choices: Am open to seeing if the mood develops
Am honest about where I'm at
Feel guilty even though I know I shouldn't
Try to connect in other ways instead

therapeutic.rationale: Responses to desire mismatch reveal patterns. Open-to-trying types sometimes warm up; honest types communicate directly; guilt-feelers struggle with saying no; alternative-connectors redirect. Understanding your pattern helps you communicate.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different responses are fine—the key is communication. The honest partner should feel safe saying no; the open-to-trying partner shouldn't feel obligated.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared response patterns help you predict and understand each other during mismatches.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel when you're not in the mood but your partner is? What do you need in those moments?

questions.text: For me, quality vs. quantity of intimacy is...
choices: Quality matters most—depth over frequency
Both matter equally to me
Frequency matters—regular connection is important
I'd rather have quality, but frequency builds connection

therapeutic.rationale: Quality vs. quantity preference reveals intimacy values. Quality-focusers want depth; both-wanters balance; frequency-focusers want regularity; quality-preferers-who-value-frequency see the role of both. Partners often prioritize differently.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different priorities may clash. The quality-focuser may not understand why frequency matters; the frequency-focuser may not understand why one good experience isn't enough for a while.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared priority makes planning your intimate life easier. You agree on what matters most.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What matters more to you—how often you're intimate or how good it is when you are? Why?
